Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 24<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 17, 2022, 11:13 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 17, 2022, 11:13 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Hi again, and thanks for getting back here!<span class="line"><!---->Hi again, and thanks for getting back here!<!----></span><br><br>As you stated, there is no way to use this to access data cross site. What I wanted to point out was the fact that this could have a bigger impact than what I felt my PoC maybe showed. I will give you an example here, and leave it to you to decide if this increases the severity.<span class="line"><!---->As you stated, there is no way to use this to access data cross site. What I wanted to point out was the fact that this could have a bigger impact than what I felt my PoC maybe showed. I will give you an example here, and leave it to you to decide if this increases the severity.<!----></span><br><br>So how I would have gone about exploiting this would take advantage of two configurations at a target site. (I draw my inspiration here from Frans Rosen's work on OAuth flows <span class="line"><!---->So how I would have gone about exploiting this would take advantage of two configurations at a target site. (I draw my inspiration here from Frans Rosen's work on OAuth flows <!----></span>https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/"><!---->https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> We need a target that allows:<span class="line"><!----> We need a target that allows:<!----></span><br><br>1. A subdomain that can contain attacker supplied JavaScript, this could be by a feature (as I will show) or by a bug (say an XSS or subdomain takeover)<span class="line"><!---->1. A subdomain that can contain attacker supplied JavaScript, this could be by a feature (as I will show) or by a bug (say an XSS or subdomain takeover)<!----></span><br>2. OAuth login<span class="line"><!---->2. OAuth login<!----></span><br>3. A way to get an OAuth flow to get into a "failed state" (se the blog post for all the details here)<span class="line"><!---->3. A way to get an OAuth flow to get into a "failed state" (se the blog post for all the details here)<!----></span><br><br>What part three really above amounts to is to find a site where the site for example only allow the `code` flow, that will return and consume any token as a query parameter. If the attacker instead asks for a `code+id_token` (from Google OAuth) the response will instead contain a code and an id_token in the fragment of the URL. And it will be stuck there as the site does not consume it.<span class="line"><!---->What part three really above amounts to is to find a site where the site for example only allow the `code` flow, that will return and consume any token as a query parameter. If the attacker instead asks for a `code+id_token` (from Google OAuth) the response will instead contain a code and an id_token in the fragment of the URL. And it will be stuck there as the site does not consume it.<!----></span><br><br>An attacker will now take advantage of the fact that IF the victim is already logged into the service (and the OAuth provider) the OAuth flow will just run through, and the user will land on a page with the unused code and any tokens in the fragment of the URL. The attacker page can now leak these tokens and codes and both steal PII from the Google API, and perform an account takeover on the targeted application.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker will now take advantage of the fact that IF the victim is already logged into the service (and the OAuth provider) the OAuth flow will just run through, and the user will land on a page with the unused code and any tokens in the fragment of the URL. The attacker page can now leak these tokens and codes and both steal PII from the Google API, and perform an account takeover on the targeted application.<!----></span><br><br>To summarize. The attacker creates a page on a subdomain<span class="line"><!---->To summarize. The attacker creates a page on a subdomain<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sub.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub.example.com"><!---->sub.example.com<!----></a> when the user click anywhere on the page, the subdomain window will open a new window containing an OAuth flow with the attacker's planted state parameter. The flow will finish and the victim (in the new window) will end up on<span class="line"><!----> when the user click anywhere on the page, the subdomain window will open a new window containing an OAuth flow with the attacker's planted state parameter. The flow will finish and the victim (in the new window) will end up on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&id_token=abc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&amp;id_token=abc"><!---->example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&amp;id_token=abc<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> The subdomain window will now use the bug from this report to leak the fragment. The attacker now have access to the victim's id_token containing PII and to the code that the attacker can use with his/her own state parameter to finish login as the victim in his/her own browser.<span class="line"><!----> The subdomain window will now use the bug from this report to leak the fragment. The attacker now have access to the victim's id_token containing PII and to the code that the attacker can use with his/her own state parameter to finish login as the victim in his/her own browser.<!----></span><br><br>I have a PoC of this working on <span class="line"><!---->I have a PoC of this working on <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io"><!---->https://codesandbox.io<!----></a> . This application allows users to host example pages under subdomains like test-site.codesandbox.io AND it allows for Google OAuth to sign in. Moreover, by changing from code flow to any fragment flow, the page will fail to log in. Thus, it checks all the three boxes from above.<span class="line"><!----> . This application allows users to host example pages under subdomains like test-site.codesandbox.io AND it allows for Google OAuth to sign in. Moreover, by changing from code flow to any fragment flow, the page will fail to log in. Thus, it checks all the three boxes from above.<!----></span><br><br>To test this:<span class="line"><!---->To test this:<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io/signin<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/signin"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/signin<!----></a> and create an account using Google OAuth (the victim), and log in<span class="line"><!----> and create an account using Google OAuth (the victim), and log in<!----></span><br>2. Open another browser session (the attacker)<span class="line"><!---->2. Open another browser session (the attacker)<!----></span><br>3. Again go to <span class="line"><!---->3. Again go to <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io/signin<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/signin"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/signin<!----></a> and click Google OAuth, but this time only copy the state parameter from the OAuth link. Do not log in.<span class="line"><!----> and click Google OAuth, but this time only copy the state parameter from the OAuth link. Do not log in.<!----></span><br>4. In the victim browser now go to my PoC page on <span class="line"><!---->4. In the victim browser now go to my PoC page on <!----></span>https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC"><!---->https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC<!----></a> and replace ABC with the state from step 3<span class="line"><!----> and replace ABC with the state from step 3<!----></span><br>5. When the page loads there will be two buttons, one will leak code and id_token, the other will leak Google API access_token (with the scope set by codesandbox)<span class="line"><!---->5. When the page loads there will be two buttons, one will leak code and id_token, the other will leak Google API access_token (with the scope set by codesandbox)<!----></span><br>6. Clicking a button will open a new window, and the attack will take 4 seconds. When it is finished go to the original tab, and you will find the leaked data in an alert box and in the terminal.<span class="line"><!---->6. Clicking a button will open a new window, and the attack will take 4 seconds. When it is finished go to the original tab, and you will find the leaked data in an alert box and in the terminal.<!----></span><br><br>The attacker can now use the returned code to finish log in as the victim in the attacker window, if you like. (replace STATE and CODE)<span class="line"><!---->The attacker can now use the returned code to finish log in as the victim in the attacker window, if you like. (replace STATE and CODE)<!----></span><br><br>https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&code=CODEw&scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&authuser=0&prompt=none<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&amp;code=CODEw&amp;scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&amp;authuser=0&amp;prompt=none"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&amp;code=CODEw&amp;scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&amp;authuser=0&amp;prompt=none<!----></a><br><br> But I think this proves the point.<span class="line"><!----> But I think this proves the point.<!----></span><br><br> So what I wanted to show here is that this flaw in Google actually put quite a lot of sites in direct danger for account takeover attacks, and to leak (scoped) access tokens to OAuth providers. I have confirmed that similar "failed states" of OAuth is possible in multiple pages <span class="line"><!----> So what I wanted to show here is that this flaw in Google actually put quite a lot of sites in direct danger for account takeover attacks, and to leak (scoped) access tokens to OAuth providers. I have confirmed that similar "failed states" of OAuth is possible in multiple pages <!----></span>(<span class="line"><!---->(<!----></span>GitLab.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://GitLab.com"><!---->GitLab.com<!----></a> for example) but an attacker would first need to find a subdomain to abuse for the attack. I do still think that this elevates this bug from just "leaking some information", but you will be the judge of that!<span class="line"><!----> for example) but an attacker would first need to find a subdomain to abuse for the attack. I do still think that this elevates this bug from just "leaking some information", but you will be the judge of that!<!----></span><br><br> If you need me to get into more details of this type of attack, I can elaborate on any part that is confusing!<span class="line"><!----> If you need me to get into more details of this type of attack, I can elaborate on any part that is confusing!<!----></span><br><br> Best regards<span class="line"><!----> Best regards<!----></span><br> Johan<span class="line"><!----> Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        A small addition to the example above. First of the PoC above is for a complete account takeover on codesandbox. To only leak a (scoped) access token to Google API, you can just put a random string as the state and click the "use token" button.<span class="line"><!---->A small addition to the example above. First of the PoC above is for a complete account takeover on codesandbox. To only leak a (scoped) access token to Google API, you can just put a random string as the state and click the "use token" button.<!----></span><br><br> I also wanted to point out that the codesandbox example do not use any other bugs. They use subdomains for user generated content, which is not great, but should be safe in this context. And the OAuth flow "failed states" issue is something that a lot of applications have and is a part of the Google OAuth flow. It should not be considered a bug per se either.<span class="line"><!----> I also wanted to point out that the codesandbox example do not use any other bugs. They use subdomains for user generated content, which is not great, but should be safe in this context. And the OAuth flow "failed states" issue is something that a lot of applications have and is a part of the Google OAuth flow. It should not be considered a bug per se either.<!----></span><br><br>If you want to test a simpler version to prove a point I will also give you this "manual PoC" on<span class="line"><!---->If you want to test a simpler version to prove a point I will also give you this "manual PoC" on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>GitLab.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://GitLab.com"><!---->GitLab.com<!----></a>.         Hi Johan, we appreciate the amount of effort you exhibited here to provide a new POC and repro steps. While we appreciate this, even with the information presented, this issue requires significant preconditions to execute and given the pre-requisite to find a victim site that meets all the criteria, this issue seems relegated to a specific set of sites and it is unclear as to how many sites would be impacted by this issue. <span class="line"><!---->Hi Johan, we appreciate the amount of effort you exhibited here to provide a new POC and repro steps. While we appreciate this, even with the information presented, this issue requires significant preconditions to execute and given the pre-requisite to find a victim site that meets all the criteria, this issue seems relegated to a specific set of sites and it is unclear as to how many sites would be impacted by this issue. <!----></span><br>While this is definitely a security issue that should have been and is now fixed, due to this issue being rather significantly mitigated, the VRP Panel feel this reward amount is appropriate for this report for this issue.<span class="line"><!---->While this is definitely a security issue that should have been and is now fixed, due to this issue being rather significantly mitigated, the VRP Panel feel this reward amount is appropriate for this report for this issue.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Of course! If there is a time we don't get back to you about a question -- please always reach out. <span class="line"><!---->Of course! If there is a time we don't get back to you about a question -- please always reach out. <!----></span><br>We also hope it's not the last report from you to us in Chrome. <span class="line"><!---->We also hope it's not the last report from you to us in Chrome. <!----></span><br><br>Our goal is to open security bugs to the public once the bug is fixed and *the fix has been shipped to a majority of users*. However, many vulnerabilities affect products besides Chromium, and we don’t want to put users of those products unnecessarily at risk by opening the bug before fixes for the other affected products have shipped.<span class="line"><!---->Our goal is to open security bugs to the public once the bug is fixed and *the fix has been shipped to a majority of users*. However, many vulnerabilities affect products besides Chromium, and we don’t want to put users of those products unnecessarily at risk by opening the bug before fixes for the other affected products have shipped.<!----></span><br><br>Therefore, we make all security bugs public within approximately 14 weeks of the fix landing in the Chromium repository. The bot will automatically remove the Restrict-View label and add the allpublic label at that time and you are then free to publicly discuss this issue. <span class="line"><!---->Therefore, we make all security bugs public within approximately 14 weeks of the fix landing in the Chromium repository. The bot will automatically remove the Restrict-View label and add the allpublic label at that time and you are then free to publicly discuss this issue. <!----></span><br>This issue considered Fixed on 3 November, so public disclosure date would be on 9 February 2023 if my math is correct. We appreciate you keeping this issue disclosed only to us until that time!<span class="line"><!---->This issue considered Fixed on 3 November, so public disclosure date would be on 9 February 2023 if my math is correct. We appreciate you keeping this issue disclosed only to us until that time!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks domenic@ :) This is less a VRP policy and more a Security policy. Because there may be multiple CLs that result in a given security issue being resolved and the because a fix CL being landed does not initiate the merge process (meaning that the fix isn't yet in the process of getting shipped and helping to close the patch gap), the sheriffbot automation leverages the date when the issue is closed as Fixed (or Verified) to initiate the 14-week countdown process. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks domenic@ :) This is less a VRP policy and more a Security policy. Because there may be multiple CLs that result in a given security issue being resolved and the because a fix CL being landed does not initiate the merge process (meaning that the fix isn't yet in the process of getting shipped and helping to close the patch gap), the sheriffbot automation leverages the date when the issue is closed as Fixed (or Verified) to initiate the 14-week countdown process. <!----></span><br>In <span class="line"><!---->In <!----></span>comment 15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->comment 15<!----></a>, the issue is marked as Fixed on 3 November (PST) / 4 November (JST) so the security/sheriffbot automation will update this bug as allpublic 14 weeks from that date. <span class="line"><!---->, the issue is marked as Fixed on 3 November (PST) / 4 November (JST) so the security/sheriffbot automation will update this bug as allpublic 14 weeks from that date. <!----></span><br><br>Johan -- If there is a deadline that is close to the public disclosure date and you're seeking to write/publicly discuss this issue a bit sooner, do please reach out. We can discuss a slightly earlier disclosure date if there is a need.<span class="line"><!---->Johan -- If there is a deadline that is close to the public disclosure date and you're seeking to write/publicly discuss this issue a bit sooner, do please reach out. We can discuss a slightly earlier disclosure date if there is a need.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by johan...@gmail.com (Sep 1, 2022)

        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I read Gareth Heyes <span class="line"><!---->I read Gareth Heyes <!----></span>https://portswigger.net/research/using-hackability-to-uncover-a-chrome-infoleak<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://portswigger.net/research/using-hackability-to-uncover-a-chrome-infoleak"><!---->https://portswigger.net/research/using-hackability-to-uncover-a-chrome-infoleak<!----></a> blog about a SOP bypass when navigating an iframe to about:blank. From what I can see his bug is since fixed. But I found another leak that can be achieved in a similar manner.<span class="line"><!----> blog about a SOP bypass when navigating an iframe to about:blank. From what I can see his bug is since fixed. But I found another leak that can be achieved in a similar manner.<!----></span><br><br>If a page on a subdomain (or domain) frames another subdomain of the same top domain it will not have access to the iframes location by SOP. But by changing the iframes location to about:blank the iframes window will now be accessible from the top window. And the window.navigation.entities() will still contain all navigation entities from the previously framed subdomain.<span class="line"><!---->If a page on a subdomain (or domain) frames another subdomain of the same top domain it will not have access to the iframes location by SOP. But by changing the iframes location to about:blank the iframes window will now be accessible from the top window. And the window.navigation.entities() will still contain all navigation entities from the previously framed subdomain.<!----></span><br><br>Example:<span class="line"><!---->Example:<!----></span><br>https://sub1.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.example.com"><!---->https://sub1.example.com<!----></a> contains<span class="line"><!----> contains<!----></span><br><br><html><span class="line"><!---->&lt;html&gt;<!----></span><br><head></head><span class="line"><!---->&lt;head&gt;&lt;/head&gt;<!----></span><br><body><span class="line"><!---->&lt;body&gt;<!----></span><br><script><span class="line"><!---->&lt;script&gt;<!----></span><br>onload = function(){<span class="line"><!---->onload = function(){<!----></span><br>    frames[0].location = 'about:blank';setTimeout(()=>alert(frames[0].navigation.entries()[0].url), 500)<span class="line"><!---->    frames[0].location = 'about:blank';setTimeout(()=&gt;alert(frames[0].navigation.entries()[0].url), 500)<!----></span><br>};<span class="line"><!---->};<!----></span><br></script><span class="line"><!---->&lt;/script&gt;<!----></span><br><br><iframe id="x" src="//sub2.example.com/test.se"></iframe><span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe id="x" src="//sub2.example.com/test.se"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;<!----></span><br><br></body><span class="line"><!---->&lt;/body&gt;<!----></span><br></html><span class="line"><!---->&lt;/html&gt;<!----></span><br><br>will show an alert from sub1 containing the url from sub2.<span class="line"><!---->will show an alert from sub1 containing the url from sub2.<!----></span><br><br>This just proves one url. If the framed subdomain have more entries in the navigation history they are all accessible from the top window at this point.<span class="line"><!---->This just proves one url. If the framed subdomain have more entries in the navigation history they are all accessible from the top window at this point.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version 105.0.5195.52 (Oficial version) (x86_64)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version 105.0.5195.52 (Oficial version) (x86_64)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Mac Os<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Mac Os<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>https://subdomain1.joaxcar.com/sop.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://subdomain1.joaxcar.com/sop.html"><!---->https://subdomain1.joaxcar.com/sop.html<!----></a><br><br>This site contains the HTML from above<span class="line"><!---->This site contains the HTML from above<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I reproduced the behavior on Windows @ 105/Stable and Linux at 102 (nominally equivalent to Extended). <span class="line"><!---->I reproduced the behavior on Windows @ 105/Stable and Linux at 102 (nominally equivalent to Extended). <!----></span><br><br>Setting severity to High since by my interpretation of our severity guidelines [1] this is an example of reading cross-origin data. However, consider the severity assessment as preliminary until others with more context on SOP bugs get a chance to take a look. <span class="line"><!---->Setting severity to High since by my interpretation of our severity guidelines [1] this is an example of reading cross-origin data.         Thanks for looking into this. I have made some more tests and a slightly more advanced PoC<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for looking into this. I have made some more tests and a slightly more advanced PoC<!----></span><br><br>From my testing the leak works in these domain scenarios<span class="line"><!---->From my testing the leak works in these domain scenarios<!----></span><br><br>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a> reading history of<span class="line"><!----> reading history of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>subdomain.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://subdomain.example.com"><!---->subdomain.example.com<!----></a><br>subdomain.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://subdomain.example.com"><!---->subdomain.example.com<!----></a> reading history of<span class="line"><!----> reading history of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a><br>subdomain1.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://subdomain1.example.com"><!---->subdomain1.example.com<!----></a> reading history of<span class="line"><!----> reading history of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>subdomain2.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://subdomain2.example.com"><!---->subdomain2.example.com<!----></a><br><br>I have not gotten it to work cross top domain<span class="line"><!---->I have not gotten it to work cross top domain<!----></span><br><br>Another addition to the impact of the bug is that it also work for windows opened by the main window. For example using window.open(). This allows for an attack to be conducted both on frames and on new windows.<span class="line"><!---->Another addition to the impact of the bug is that it also work for windows opened by the main window. For example using window.open(). This allows for an attack to be conducted both on frames and on new windows.<!----></span><br><br>To demonstrate the leak I have set up this site <span class="line"><!---->To demonstrate the leak I have set up this site <!----></span>https://sub1.joaxcar.com/1.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.joaxcar.com/1.html"><!---->https://sub1.joaxcar.com/1.html<!----></a> that contains a frame of <span class="line"><!----> that contains a frame of <!----></span>https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html"><!---->https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html<!----></a> . You can navigate around in the frame to create some history and then click the "Leak history" in the man window to extract the history from the frame. I also use history.back() on the frame after the leak to restore the users session. This will make the attack almost invisible to the user of the page who will be able to continue using the frame.<span class="line"><!----> . You can navigate around in the frame to create some history and then click the "Leak history" in the man window to extract the history from the frame. I also use history.back() on the frame after the leak to restore the users session. This will make the attack almost invisible to the user of the page who will be able to continue using the frame.<!----></span><br><br>The page also contains a PoC opening a new window by clicking a button. This will open a new window with <span class="line"><!---->The page also contains a PoC opening a new window by clicking a button. This will open a new window with <!----></span>https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html"><!---->https://blog.joaxcar.com/sop2/2.html<!----></a> where you can navigate around. Then go back. to the original tab and click "Leak history from window" and you will leak the new tabs history.<span class="line"><!----> where you can navigate around. Then go back. to the original tab and click "Leak history from window" and you will leak the new tabs history.<!----></span><br><br>I have attached the HTML files used. To test locally just host the files with for example "python3 -m http.server 8000" and edit your /etc/hosts file to add some mock domains. Remember to update the 1.html file to reflect your mock domain and port number to localhost. My hosts file entries<span class="line"><!---->I have attached the HTML files used. To test locally just host the files with for example "python3 -m http.server 8000" and edit your /etc/hosts file to add some mock domains. Remember to update the 1.html file to reflect your mock domain and port number to localhost. My hosts file entries<!----></span><br><br>127.0.0.1<span class="line"><!---->127.0.0.1<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sub1.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.example.com"><!---->sub1.example.com<!----></a><br>127.0.0.1<span class="line"><!---->127.0.0.1<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sub2.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub2.example.com"><!---->sub2.example.com<!----></a><br>127.0.0.1<span class="line"><!---->127.0.0.1<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a><br><br>start the server and visit <span class="line"><!---->start the server and visit <!----></span>http://sub1.example.com:8000/1.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sub1.example.com:8000/1.html"><!---->http://sub1.example.com:8000/1.html<!----></a><br><br>Hope this helps to evaluate the impact here.<span class="line"><!---->Hope this helps to evaluate the impact here.<!----></span><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        And as this also work with window objects, there is also an other risk, which is leaking history through the opener. If a link with rel=opener is opened or if window.open() is used without blocking opener the opened window can leak the opening windows history.<span class="line"><!---->And as this also work with window objects, there is also an other risk, which is leaking history through the opener. If a link with rel=opener is opened or if window.open() is used without blocking opener the opened window can leak the opening windows history.<!----></span><br><br>Clicking a link like this one (on a page on<span class="line"><!---->Clicking a link like this one (on a page on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sub1.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.example.com"><!---->sub1.example.com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br> <a href="<span class="line"><!----> &lt;a href="<!----></span>http://sub2.example.com/5.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sub2.example.com/5.html"><!---->http://sub2.example.com/5.html<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> rel="opener" target="_blank"><span class="line"><!----> rel="opener" target="_blank"&gt;<!----></span><br><br>will allow the opened window to leak the navigation history as described above.<span class="line"><!---->will allow the opened window to leak the navigation history as described above.<!----></span><br><br>I have a working PoC here<span class="line"><!---->I have a working PoC here<!----></span><br>https://sub1.joaxcar.com/4.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.joaxcar.com/4.html"><!---->https://sub1.joaxcar.com/4.html<!----></a><br><br>Click on some of the navigation and then click "open window", this will open a page on<span class="line"><!---->Click on some of the navigation and then click "open window", this will open a page on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>blog.joaxcar.com<a class="undefined"         japhet@: This looks like a problem with the Navigation API's window.navigation.entries() field, possibly leaving stale information around within the renderer process after a navigation (e.g., to about:blank).  Can you take a look?  And can you note when the Navigation API shipped?  Is M102 the right starting point to use?<span class="line"><!---->japhet@: This looks like a problem with the Navigation API's window.navigation.entries() field, possibly leaving stale information around within the renderer process after a navigation (e.g., to about:blank).  Can you take a look?  And can you note when the Navigation API shipped?  Is M102 the right starting point to use?<!----></span><br><br>For reference, I think the original report's blog post link about inspiration was referring to <span class="line"><!---->For reference, I think the original report's blog post link about inspiration was referring to <!----></span>issue 1336904<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1336904" title="An iframe on a different domain can change the location to about:blank which enables you to access properties on the window. document.baseURI is leaked from the parent frame."><!---->issue 1336904<!----></a>.  That was classified as low severity, likely because it's an information leak of baseURI, which leaks some bits of history but not significant amounts of cross-origin data.<span class="line"><!---->.  That was classified as low severity, likely because it's an information leak of baseURI, which leaks some bits of history but not significant amounts of cross-origin data.<!----></span><br><br>In this bug, there's also no direct access to the victim origin: mainly a leak of URLs from history (which is more of a privacy leak than security, but admittedly can sometimes contain login tokens, etc).  Another mitigating factor is that it doesn't appear to bypass Site Isolation, and only affects cross-origin, same-site cases that are likely in the same process.  It'll be worth confirming if the process boundary is sufficient, and if origin-level isolation (e.g., using Origin-Agent-Cluster) would have helped, but that's not a mitigating factor on its own (given the low rollout of that so far).<span class="line"><!---->In this bug, there's also no direct access to the victim origin: mainly a leak of URLs from history (which is more of a privacy leak than security, but admittedly can sometimes contain login tokens, etc).  Another mitigating factor is that it doesn't appear to bypass Site Isolation, and only affects cross-origin, same-site cases that are likely in the same process.  It'll be worth confirming if the process boundary is sufficient, and if origin-level isolation (e.g., using Origin-Agent-Cluster) would have helped, but that's not a mitigating factor on its own (given the low rollout of that so far).<!----></span><br><br>Since this is a limited leak of information (URL history) in limited cases (same-site), I'll drop this to at least medium severity, but we should better compare the full impact of this to the full impact of <span class="line"><!---->Since this is a limited leak of information (URL history) in limited cases (same-site), I'll drop this to at least medium severity, but we should better compare the full impact of this to the full impact of <!----></span>issue 1336904<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1336904" title="An iframe on a different domain can change the location to about:blank which enables you to access properties on the window. document.baseURI is leaked from the parent frame."><!---->issue 1336904<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to see if they should both be low or both be medium.<span class="line"><!---->to see if they should both be low or both be medium.<!----></span><br><br>bookholt@: Was there a reason for the Needs-Feedback label?  I didn't see a question in <span class="line"><!---->bookholt@: Was there a reason for the Needs-Feedback label?  I didn't see a question in <!----></span>comment 1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c1"><!---->comment 1<!----></a>, so I'll remove that for now.<span class="line"><!---->, so I'll remove that for now.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 5<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      johan...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/3529797889" title="johan...@gmail.com"><!---->johan...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      johan...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->johan...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Fri, Sep 2, 2022, 5:54 PM EDT

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Sep 2, 2022, 5:54 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Sep 2, 2022, 5:54 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I can try to add some information about impact in regard to the 1336904 bug.<span class="line"><!---->I can try to add some information about impact in regard to the 1336904 bug.<!----></span><br><br>The bug described by Gareth in 1336904 had these preconditions:<span class="line"><!---->The bug described by Gareth in 1336904 had these preconditions:<!----></span><br><br>An attacker would need to find a frameable page that contained at least one iframe. By framing the page in an attacker controlled page, the attacker could then change the inner iframe to about:blank to extract the current URL from the framed page. This is quite restrictive as a lot of pages containing any data of value in their URL are not frameable. But it seems like the attack would work on any frameable page, no mather domain (I have not confirmed this). The victim do need to interact with the framed page on the attackers domain though.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker would need to find a frameable page that contained at least one iframe. By framing the page in an attacker controlled page, the attacker could then change the inner iframe to about:blank to extract the current URL from the framed page. This is quite restrictive as a lot of pages containing any data of value in their URL are not frameable. But it seems like the attack would work on any frameable page, no mather domain (I have not confirmed this). The victim do need to interact with the framed page on the attackers domain though.<!----></span><br><br>So to summarize 1336904. An attacker could embed a frameable page containing an inner iframe and then leak the middle frames current URL.<span class="line"><!---->So to summarize 1336904. An attacker could embed a frameable page containing an inner iframe and then leak the middle frames current URL.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The issue described here have some different conditions (most of them adding to the severity I would argue):<span class="line"><!---->The issue described here have some different conditions (most of them adding to the severity I would argue):<!----></span><br>1. An attacker can first of all get a lot more information out of a successful attack (I have had tabs with over hundred entries in the navigation history) so the possibility to leak sensitive data is way higher.<span class="line"><!---->1. An attacker can first of all get a lot more information out of a successful attack (I have had tabs with over hundred entries in the navigation history) so the possibility to leak sensitive data is way higher.<!----></span><br>2. There is no need for an iframe in the window one wants to target. If the target is framable it can be used in the same way as in 1336904, but without the restriction of also having an iframe of its own<span class="line"><!---->2. There is no need for an iframe in the window one wants to target. If the target is framable it can be used in the same way as in 1336904, but without the restriction of also having an iframe of its own<!----></span><br>3. The attack can also be made against window objects, making it possible to target pages that do not allow for cross origin framing. And it also opens up for the attack to be made "from the inside out" by attacking the opener of a window if the attacker controls a rel=opener link in the target page or can inject a link in a window.open action (this is more of an escalation of a regular "tab nabbing" vulnerability). In this case the user will also interact with the victim page on the original domain, unknowingly that another window can read the actions.<span class="line"><!---->3. The attack can also be made against window objects, making it possible to target pages that do not allow for cross origin framing. And it also opens up for the attack to be made "from the inside out" by attacking the opener of a window if the attacker controls a rel=opener link in the target page or can inject a link in a window.open action (this is more of an escalation of a regular "tab nabbing" vulnerability). In this case the user will also interact with the victim page on the original domain, unknowingly that another window can read the actions.<!----></span><br><br>What is restricting the attack, as you pointed out, is that it can only be made "same site". This is a big restriction but is highly dangerous on services that allow for users to work under a subdomain. I have verified that the behavior is effective on some large service providers, but restricted on some. I have yet not found what mitigation is restricting access on some domains.<span class="line"><!---->What is restricting the attack, as you pointed out, is that it can only be made "same site". This is a big restriction but is highly dangerous on services that allow for users to work under a subdomain. I have verified that the behavior is effective on some large service providers, but restricted on some. I have yet not found what mitigation is restricting access on some domains.<!----></span><br><br>To summarize, I belive that the risk of sensitive information disclosure is higher in this scenario despite the same site restriction. I hope that this helps pin it down somewhat. I will get back if I find out what type of mitigations there are to this issue at present.<span class="line"><!---->To summarize, I belive that the risk of sensitive information disclosure is higher in this scenario despite the same site restriction. I hope that this helps pin it down somewhat. I will get back if I find out what type of mitigations there are to this issue at present.<!----></span><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        Good catch!<span class="line"><!---->Good catch!<!----></span><br><br>NavigationApi usuaslly gets entries() from the browser process for a cross-document navigation, but when navigating to about:blank, we copy from the previous NavigationApi object (because the browser process isn't involved in about:blank navigations). I didn't consider the cross-origin -> about:blank case in implementing that copy logic.<span class="line"><!---->NavigationApi usuaslly gets entries() from the browser process for a cross-document navigation, but when navigating to about:blank, we copy from the previous NavigationApi object (because the browser process isn't involved in about:blank navigations). I didn't consider the cross-origin -&gt; about:blank case in implementing that copy logic.<!----></span><br><br>As creis@ noted, site isolation defends against the worst variants of this leak (only cross-origin-but-same-site will leak with site isolation enabled; without it, cross-site will leak, too). That's because the cross-site case swaps processes when navigating to about:blank with site isolation enabled, and that allows us to use the correct logic in the browser process.<span class="line"><!---->As creis@ noted, site isolation defends against the worst variants of this leak (only cross-origin-but-same-site will leak with site isolation enabled; without it, cross-site will leak, too). That's because the cross-site case swaps processes when navigating to about:blank with site isolation enabled, and that allows us to use the correct logic in the browser process.<!----></span><br><br>The fix is striaghtforward and out for review: <span class="line"><!---->The fix is striaghtforward and out for review: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3878043<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3878043"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3878043<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Hi again, great to see that a fix is on the way!<span class="line"><!---->Hi again, great to see that a fix is on the way!<!----></span><br><br>I just wanted to add some additional impact here as I have been playing around with the navigation API. The API also includes a concept of "state" which gives developers the ability to store any object type state data connected to a specific history entry. I just wanted to point out that these states are also leaked through this attack, in addition to just the URLs.<span class="line"><!---->I just wanted to add some additional impact here as I have been playing around with the navigation API. The API also includes a concept of "state" which gives developers the ability to store any object type state data connected to a specific history entry. I just wanted to point out that these states are also leaked through this attack, in addition to just the URLs.<!----></span><br><br>An, hacky, example can be viewed here: <span class="line"><!---->An, hacky, example can be viewed here: <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/state.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/state.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/state.html<!----></a><br><br>I load the page <span class="line"><!---->I load the page <!----></span>https://sub1.joaxcar.com/links3.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub1.joaxcar.com/links3.html"><!---->https://sub1.joaxcar.com/links3.html<!----></a> in an iframe, this page just sets a state item to the current navigation entry. The main page then navigates the iframe to about:blank and shows an alert with the leaked state data<span class="line"><!----> in an iframe, this page just sets a state item to the current navigation entry. The main page then navigates the iframe to about:blank and shows an alert with the leaked state data<!----></span><br><br>The two pages are attached, there is not much new in terms of content in the pages. The important part is that this state data is leaked.<span class="line"><!---->The two pages are attached, there is not much new in terms of content in the pages. The important part is that this state data is leaked.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks again for fixing this!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks again for fixing this!<!----></span><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          -reward-topanel reward-unpaid reward-2000
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 24<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 17, 2022, 11:13 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1359122#c24">Comment 24<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 17, 2022, 11:13 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Hi again, and thanks for getting back here!<span class="line"><!---->Hi again, and thanks for getting back here!<!----></span><br><br>As you stated, there is no way to use this to access data cross site. What I wanted to point out was the fact that this could have a bigger impact than what I felt my PoC maybe showed. I will give you an example here, and leave it to you to decide if this increases the severity.<span class="line"><!---->As you stated, there is no way to use this to access data cross site. What I wanted to point out was the fact that this could have a bigger impact than what I felt my PoC maybe showed. I will give you an example here, and leave it to you to decide if this increases the severity.<!----></span><br><br>So how I would have gone about exploiting this would take advantage of two configurations at a target site. (I draw my inspiration here from Frans Rosen's work on OAuth flows <span class="line"><!---->So how I would have gone about exploiting this would take advantage of two configurations at a target site. (I draw my inspiration here from Frans Rosen's work on OAuth flows <!----></span>https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/"><!---->https://labs.detectify.com/2022/07/06/account-hijacking-using-dirty-dancing-in-sign-in-oauth-flows/<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> We need a target that allows:<span class="line"><!----> We need a target that allows:<!----></span><br><br>1. A subdomain that can contain attacker supplied JavaScript, this could be by a feature (as I will show) or by a bug (say an XSS or subdomain takeover)<span class="line"><!---->1. A subdomain that can contain attacker supplied JavaScript, this could be by a feature (as I will show) or by a bug (say an XSS or subdomain takeover)<!----></span><br>2. OAuth login<span class="line"><!---->2. OAuth login<!----></span><br>3. A way to get an OAuth flow to get into a "failed state" (se the blog post for all the details here)<span class="line"><!---->3. A way to get an OAuth flow to get into a "failed state" (se the blog post for all the details here)<!----></span><br><br>What part three really above amounts to is to find a site where the site for example only allow the `code` flow, that will return and consume any token as a query parameter. If the attacker instead asks for a `code+id_token` (from Google OAuth) the response will instead contain a code and an id_token in the fragment of the URL. And it will be stuck there as the site does not consume it.<span class="line"><!---->What part three really above amounts to is to find a site where the site for example only allow the `code` flow, that will return and consume any token as a query parameter. If the attacker instead asks for a `code+id_token` (from Google OAuth) the response will instead contain a code and an id_token in the fragment of the URL. And it will be stuck there as the site does not consume it.<!----></span><br><br>An attacker will now take advantage of the fact that IF the victim is already logged into the service (and the OAuth provider) the OAuth flow will just run through, and the user will land on a page with the unused code and any tokens in the fragment of the URL. The attacker page can now leak these tokens and codes and both steal PII from the Google API, and perform an account takeover on the targeted application.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker will now take advantage of the fact that IF the victim is already logged into the service (and the OAuth provider) the OAuth flow will just run through, and the user will land on a page with the unused code and any tokens in the fragment of the URL. The attacker page can now leak these tokens and codes and both steal PII from the Google API, and perform an account takeover on the targeted application.<!----></span><br><br>To summarize. The attacker creates a page on a subdomain<span class="line"><!---->To summarize. The attacker creates a page on a subdomain<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sub.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sub.example.com"><!---->sub.example.com<!----></a> when the user click anywhere on the page, the subdomain window will open a new window containing an OAuth flow with the attacker's planted state parameter. The flow will finish and the victim (in the new window) will end up on<span class="line"><!----> when the user click anywhere on the page, the subdomain window will open a new window containing an OAuth flow with the attacker's planted state parameter. The flow will finish and the victim (in the new window) will end up on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&id_token=abc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&amp;id_token=abc"><!---->example.com/auth/callback#code=abc&amp;id_token=abc<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> The subdomain window will now use the bug from this report to leak the fragment. The attacker now have access to the victim's id_token containing PII and to the code that the attacker can use with his/her own state parameter to finish login as the victim in his/her own browser.<span class="line"><!----> The subdomain window will now use the bug from this report to leak the fragment. The attacker now have access to the victim's id_token containing PII and to the code that the attacker can use with his/her own state parameter to finish login as the victim in his/her own browser.<!----></span><br><br>I have a PoC of this working on <span class="line"><!---->I have a PoC of this working on <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io"><!---->https://codesandbox.io<!----></a> . This application allows users to host example pages under subdomains like test-site.codesandbox.io AND it allows for Google OAuth to sign in. Moreover, by changing from code flow to any fragment flow, the page will fail to log in. Thus, it checks all the three boxes from above.<span class="line"><!----> . This application allows users to host example pages under subdomains like test-site.codesandbox.io AND it allows for Google OAuth to sign in. Moreover, by changing from code flow to any fragment flow, the page will fail to log in. Thus, it checks all the three boxes from above.<!----></span><br><br>To test this:<span class="line"><!---->To test this:<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io/signin<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/signin"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/signin<!----></a> and create an account using Google OAuth (the victim), and log in<span class="line"><!----> and create an account using Google OAuth (the victim), and log in<!----></span><br>2. Open another browser session (the attacker)<span class="line"><!---->2. Open another browser session (the attacker)<!----></span><br>3. Again go to <span class="line"><!---->3. Again go to <!----></span>https://codesandbox.io/signin<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/signin"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/signin<!----></a> and click Google OAuth, but this time only copy the state parameter from the OAuth link. Do not log in.<span class="line"><!----> and click Google OAuth, but this time only copy the state parameter from the OAuth link. Do not log in.<!----></span><br>4. In the victim browser now go to my PoC page on <span class="line"><!---->4. In the victim browser now go to my PoC page on <!----></span>https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC"><!---->https://joaxcar-poc-3t059v.codesandbox.io/?state=ABC<!----></a> and replace ABC with the state from step 3<span class="line"><!----> and replace ABC with the state from step 3<!----></span><br>5. When the page loads there will be two buttons, one will leak code and id_token, the other will leak Google API access_token (with the scope set by codesandbox)<span class="line"><!---->5. When the page loads there will be two buttons, one will leak code and id_token, the other will leak Google API access_token (with the scope set by codesandbox)<!----></span><br>6. Clicking a button will open a new window, and the attack will take 4 seconds. When it is finished go to the original tab, and you will find the leaked data in an alert box and in the terminal.<span class="line"><!---->6. Clicking a button will open a new window, and the attack will take 4 seconds. When it is finished go to the original tab, and you will find the leaked data in an alert box and in the terminal.<!----></span><br><br>The attacker can now use the returned code to finish log in as the victim in the attacker window, if you like. (replace STATE and CODE)<span class="line"><!---->The attacker can now use the returned code to finish log in as the victim in the attacker window, if you like. (replace STATE and CODE)<!----></span><br><br>https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&code=CODEw&scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&authuser=0&prompt=none<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&amp;code=CODEw&amp;scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&amp;authuser=0&amp;prompt=none"><!---->https://codesandbox.io/auth/google/callback?state=STATE&amp;code=CODEw&amp;scope=email+profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.profile+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fuserinfo.email+openid&amp;authuser=0&amp;prompt=none<!----></a><br><br> But I think this proves the point.<span class="line"><!----> But I think this proves the point.<!----></span><br><br> So what I wanted to show here is that this flaw in Google actually put quite a lot of sites in direct danger for account takeover attacks, and to leak (scoped) access tokens to OAuth providers. I have confirmed that similar "failed states" of OAuth is possible in multiple pages <span class="line"><!----> So what I wanted to show here is that this flaw in Google actually put quite a lot of sites in direct danger for account takeover attacks, and to leak (scoped) access tokens to OAuth providers. I have confirmed that similar "failed states" of OAuth is possible in multiple pages <!----></span>(<span class="line"><!---->(<!----></span>GitLab.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://GitLab.com"><!---->GitLab.com<!----></a> for example) but an attacker would first need to find a subdomain to abuse for the attack. I do still think that this elevates this bug from just "leaking some information", but you will be the judge of that!<span class="line"><!----> for example) but an attacker would first need to find a subdomain to abuse for the attack. I do still think that this elevates this bug from just "leaking some information", but you will be the judge of that!<!----></span><br><br> If you need me to get into more details of this type of attack, I can elaborate on any part that is confusing!<span class="line"><!----> If you need me to get into more details of this type of attack, I can elaborate on any part that is confusing!<!----></span><br><br> Best regards<span class="line"><!----> Best regards<!----></span><br> Johan<span class="line"><!----> Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        A small addition to the example above. First of the PoC above is for a complete account takeover on codesandbox. To only leak a (scoped) access token to Google API, you can just put a random string as the state and click the "use token" button.<span class="line"><!---->A small addition to the example above. First of the PoC above is for a complete account takeover on codesandbox. To only leak a (scoped) access token to Google API, you can just put a random string as the state and click the "use token" button.<!----></span><br><br> I also wanted to point out that the codesandbox example do not use any other bugs. They use subdomains for user generated content, which is not great, but should be safe in this context. And the OAuth flow "failed states" issue is something that a lot of applications have and is a part of the Google OAuth flow. It should not be considered a bug per se either.<span class="line"><!----> I also wanted to point out that the codesandbox example do not use any other bugs. They use subdomains for user generated content, which is not great, but should be safe in this context.         Hi Johan, we appreciate the amount of effort you exhibited here to provide a new POC and repro steps. While we appreciate this, even with the information presented, this issue requires significant preconditions to execute and given the pre-requisite to find a victim site that meets all the criteria, this issue seems relegated to a specific set of sites and it is unclear as to how many sites would be impacted by this issue. <span class="line"><!---->Hi Johan, we appreciate the amount of effort you exhibited here to provide a new POC and repro steps. While we appreciate this, even with the information presented, this issue requires significant preconditions to execute and given the pre-requisite to find a victim site that meets all the criteria, this issue seems relegated to a specific set of sites and it is unclear as to how many sites would be impacted by this issue. <!----></span><br>While this is definitely a security issue that should have been and is now fixed, due to this issue being rather significantly mitigated, the VRP Panel feel this reward amount is appropriate for this report for this issue.<span class="line"><!---->While this is definitely a security issue that should have been and is now fixed, due to this issue being rather significantly mitigated, the VRP Panel feel this reward amount is appropriate for this report for this issue.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Of course! If there is a time we don't get back to you about a question -- please always reach out. <span class="line"><!---->Of course! If there is a time we don't get back to you about a question -- please always reach out. <!----></span><br>We also hope it's not the last report from you to us in Chrome. <span class="line"><!---->We also hope it's not the last report from you to us in Chrome. <!----></span><br><br>Our goal is to open security bugs to the public once the bug is fixed and *the fix has been shipped to a majority of users*. However, many vulnerabilities affect products besides Chromium, and we don’t want to put users of those products unnecessarily at risk by opening the bug before fixes for the other affected products have shipped.<span class="line"><!---->Our goal is to open security bugs to the public once the bug is fixed and *the fix has been shipped to a majority of users*. However, many vulnerabilities affect products besides Chromium, and we don’t want to put users of those products unnecessarily at risk by opening the bug before fixes for the other affected products have shipped.<!----></span><br><br>Therefore, we make all security bugs public within approximately 14 weeks of the fix landing in the Chromium repository. The bot will automatically remove the Restrict-View label and add the allpublic label at that time and you are then free to publicly discuss this issue. <span class="line"><!---->Therefore, we make all security bugs public within approximately 14 weeks of the fix landing in the Chromium repository. The bot will automatically remove the Restrict-View label and add the allpublic label at that time and you are then free to publicly discuss this issue. <!----></span><br>This issue considered Fixed on 3 November, so public disclosure date would be on 9 February 2023 if my math is correct. We appreciate you keeping this issue disclosed only to us until that time!<span class="line"><!---->This issue considered Fixed on 3 November, so public disclosure date would be on 9 February 2023 if my math is correct.         by

        Thanks domenic@ :) This is less a VRP policy and more a Security policy. Because there may be multiple CLs that result in a given security issue being resolved and the because a fix CL being landed does not initiate the merge process (meaning that the fix isn't yet in the process of getting shipped and helping to close the patch gap), the sheriffbot automation leverages the date when the issue is closed as Fixed (or Verified) to initiate the 14-week countdown process. <span class="line"><!---->Thanks domenic@ :) This is less a VRP policy and more a Security policy. Because there may be multiple CLs that result in a given security issue being resolved and the because a fix CL being landed does not initiate the merge process (meaning that the fix isn't yet in the process of getting shipped and helping to close the patch gap), the sheriffbot automation leverages the date when the issue is closed as Fixed (or Verified) to initiate the 14-week countdown process. <!----></span><br>In <span class="line"><!---->In <!----></span>comment 15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->comment 15<!----></a>, the issue is marked as Fixed on 3 November (PST) / 4 November (JST) so the security/sheriffbot automation will update this bug as allpublic 14 weeks from that date. <span class="line"><!---->, the issue is marked as Fixed on 3 November (PST) / 4 November (JST) so the security/sheriffbot automation will update this bug as allpublic 14 weeks from that date. <!----></span><br><br>Johan -- If there is a deadline that is close to the public disclosure date and you're seeking to write/publicly discuss this issue a bit sooner, do please reach out. We can discuss a slightly earlier disclosure date if there is a need.<span class="line"><!---->Johan -- If there is a deadline that is close to the public disclosure date and you're seeking to write/publicly discuss this issue a bit sooner, do please reach out. We can discuss a slightly earlier disclosure date if there is a need.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        <div class="target-project-dialog">
          <h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          <div class="input-grid">
            <label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>

 window.getTSMonClient().recordIssueDetailSpaTiming();

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
